journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Non-probabilistic wear reliability analysis of swash-plate/slipper of water hydraulic piston motor based on convex model

contrib-group.aff: College of Mechanical Engineering and Applied Electronics Technology, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China

author-notes.corresp: Songlin Nie, College of Mechanical Engineering and Applied Electronics Technology, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing 100124, China. Email: niesonglin@bjut.edu.cn

abstract.p: Water hydraulic piston motor is one of the important transmission components in a water hydraulic system. For lack of enough experimental information to analyze the reliability in water hydraulic motor design, the convex model is chosen as wear reliability model for hydraulic friction pairs, which is more economical and reasonable than the interval model. The non-probabilistic reliability index based on the convex model is established using first-order Taylor series expansion, and the non-probabilistic reliability model of wear reliability analysis for the friction pair of swash-plate/slipper in water hydraulic piston motor is introduced based on the convex model. For the non-probabilistic reliability model, only the bounds on uncertain parameters are needed, instead of probabilistic density distribution or statistical quantities. Numerical examples are used to illustrate the validity and feasibility of the presented method.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Water hydraulics operated by fresh water or seawater instead of mineral oil has become more and more popular owing to the advantages such as environmental friendliness, non-flammability, cheapness, cleanliness and easy disposal.1–3 However, the applications of water hydraulics should be based on the high performance and long-life service of the water hydraulic components. The water hydraulic motor (WHM) is one of the important transmission components in a water hydraulic system. Generally, there exist several types of WHMs, such as gear motors, vane motors and piston motors. However, WHM works with high-pressure and high-speed owing to the high pv values of friction pairs and the severe wear subject to the repeated alternating loads.4,5 Bhushan and Gray6 investigated several material combinations under high load and speed in synthetic seawater. They reported that the pv values of friction pairs in an axial piston motor were each one-third of those in a vane motor and one-tenth of those in a gear motor when the friction pairs adopted an identical material combination. Therefore, the axial piston motor is recognized as a preferable selection for a WHM in order to acquire lower pv values for the friction pairs.

Water hydraulic axial piston motors (WHAPMs) were developed in countries such as the UK, Denmark, Finland, US and Japan.7–13 Even though a few prototypes of water hydraulic axial piston motors were developed, full attention was not paid for its durability for designing WHAPM. Empirical approaches for designing oil hydraulic motors were still employed for WHAPMs. According to Sun and Xu,14 the assembly for the piston and the sealed zone of the plate valve that were designed through the previous empirical methods could not guarantee proper operation especially durability of the WHAPM. Severe wear between the plate valve and the bearing plate or between the slipper pad and the swash-plate may occur frequently. Therefore, it is essential that the wear reliability analysis be undertaken for the key friction pairs in the WHAPM design stage. Sun et al.15,16 set up the reliability model for the key friction pairs based on probabilistic reliability theory. They used stress–strength interference model to analyze the friction pairs, where the actual pv value and the limited pv value are considered as stress and strength of normal distributions, respectively. The above probabilistic method needs to have enough information to determine the probability distributions or the membership functions. However, useful technical data for the friction pairs of WHM are often insufficient. Generally, the interval bounds on the uncertain parameters can be obtained more easily than the probability distributions or the membership functions. It is difficult to give an authoritative density distribution due to the scarce experimental data for justifying the probabilistic reliability model appropriately. Obviously, the subjective assumptions and the absence of adequate statistical information in describing the probability model may yield unreliable results.

Convex model and interval model are two non-probabilistic methods based on non-probability indicators, which need less deterministic information. For example, Elishakoff17 proposed the notion of the non-probabilistic safety factor. If the stress is a non-probabilistic but the strength is deterministic variable, it is defined as the ratio of the strength to the upper bound of the stress; On the contrary, if the stress is deterministic but the strength is a non-probabilistic variable, it is defined as the ratio of the lower bound of the strength to the stress; generally, if both the stress and strength are interval variables, the non-probabilistic safety factor is defined as the ratio of the lower bound of the strength to the upper bound of the stress. Ben-Haim18 proposed the concept of the non-probabilistic reliability of structures, which was later called as the robust reliability. He argued that the system is reliable if the accuracy of uncertainty is allowed to fluctuate within a certain range, but he did not provide a specific non-probabilistic reliability measure method. Based on interval analysis, Elishakoff19 was the first to propose a quantitative measure of the non-probabilistic reliability. The notion of ‘non-probabilistic reliability’ was embraced by several investigators. Guo et al.20,21 quantified the uncertain structural parameters as interval variables and proposed another measure of the non-probabilistic reliability, which was taken as the shortest distance from the origin to the failure surface. Qiu et al.22,23 suggested a non-probabilistic convex reliability model by using the partial order relation of the superscribed hyperrectangle or interval vectors. Zhang et al.24 concluded that the range of non-probabilistic reliability index based on the interval model is always larger than the non-probabilistic reliability index based on convex model. The non-probabilistic reliability based on the interval model is conservative than the convex model; the convex model based on non-probability indicators is more economical, and a reasonable indicator. Based on the non-probabilistic convex model, Wang et al.25 suggested the ratio of the volume of the uncertain variables safe region to the total volume of the region of the variation as the structural non-probabilistic reliability. Wang et al.26 illustrated that the probability and convexity concepts were not antagonistic and introduced a new non-probabilistic convex model for structural reliability analysis. By numerical example, they verified that the interval model is more conservative than the measure based on the convex model. Additionally, utilizing the proposed convex model to calculate the reliability (i.e. Rellipsoid) was easy practically. If probabilistic information was available, it should be fully exploited for the derivation of the probabilistic reliability; however, if the information on densities was missing, the non-probabilistic reliability method had to be used, which treated the unknown density as if it was a uniform one. The non-probabilistic reliability method based on the convex model appeared to be an efficient technique.

Considering the water hydraulic motor is expensive at the present time, singleton-production, scant information with uncertainty, the non-probabilistic reliability method based on the convex model is more reasonable, and it is employed to analyze the wear reliability of the friction pairs. In this research, the non-probabilistic reliability method will be introduced using first-order Taylor series expansion, and its application to the swash-plate/slipper pad will be presented based on the convex model. Numerical examples will be used to illustrate the validity and feasibility of the presented method.

sec.title: Convex model reliability analysis
sec.p: The non-probabilistic analysis based on the convex model with uncertainty has been developed in engineering application.26,27 The convex model utilizes the imperfect, scanty knowledge on uncertain quantities, instead of precise information on the probability contents of random variables. The model uses a representation of uncertain phenomena by convex sets such as hyper-ellipsoid.

sec.title: Non-probabilistic reliability index
sec.p: Given X=(x1,x2,…,xm) is a vector of uncertain variables, where xi∈XiI(i=1,2,…,n). XiI is an interval region of [xiL,xiU]. xiL and xiU are the lower bound and upper bound, respectively. M(X)=g(X)=g(x1,…,xn) is the state function, where g(x1,…,xn) is a continuous function of xi(i=1,2,…,n), M is also a interval variable. Mc and Mr are the mean value and the deviation of M respectively. In the non-probabilistic reliability theory,17 the non-probabilistic reliability index is defined as (1)η=McMr where η is the non-probabilistic reliability index, which is defined as the ratio of interval mean value to deviation. If η>1, for ∀xi∈XiI (i=1,2,…,n), g(X)>0, the structure is safe and reliable. If η<-1, for ∀xi∈XiI (i=1,2,…,n), g(X)<0, the structure is a failure inevitably. If-1<η<1, for ∀xi∈XiI (i=1,2,…,n), both g(X)>0 and g(X)<0 are possible, the structure may be failed or safe. Obviously, the structure cannot be absolutely reliable. If the variables are uncertain, the structure only has two results: reliable or unreliable. The bigger value η is, the higher the safety degree of the structure is. Therefore, η can be defined as the safety measure of the structure reliability.

sec.title: Non-probabilistic reliability model based on convex model
sec.p: Ben-Haim and Elishakoff27 proposed convex set model to describe the uncertain variables, namely using the hyper-ellipsoid to describe the uncertain variable range. The non-probabilistic reliability index based on the structure of the convex set model is defined as24 (2)η=McMr=MU+MLMU-ML Where (3)MU=maxg(x1,x2,…,xn) (4)ML=ming(x1,x2,…,xn)

The state function g(x1,…,xn) can be carried out by a first-order Taylor expansion and a small high-order amount around the mean value X0 can be spent. The following equation is obtained (6)g(X)=g(X0+δX)=g(X0) +∑i=1n∂g(X0)∂xiδxi=g0+(grad)TδX where g0=g(X0);grad=(∂g(X0)∂x1,∂g(X0)∂x2,…,∂g(X0)∂xn)T

Mathematical optimization theory has been confirmed that extreme value for equation (6) is achieved at the border region of the hyper-ellipsoid shell expressed by equation (5). That is to say, solving the extreme value of the state function g(X) can be converted into solving the extreme value under a constraint condition. Thus (7)Gextreme=extremumδXTΩδX=θ2(g0+(grad)TδX)
With the help of Lagrangian multiplier method, the Lagrangian function can be defined as (8)L=g0+(grad)TδX+λ(δXTΩδX-θ2) Where λ is named as Lagrangian multiplier.
The following equation can be obtained (9){∂L∂δX=grad+2λΩδX=0∂L∂λ=δXTΩδX-θ2=0
With equations (7) to (9), the extreme values δX and Gextreme are obtained. (10){δX=±θ(grad)TΩ-1gradΩ-1gradGexetreme=g0±θ(grad)TΩ-1grad
Then, the upper and lower values of the function g(X) can be expressed respectively (11){g¯(X)=gmax=g0+θ(grad)TΩ-1gradg¯(X)=gmin=g0-θ(grad)TΩ-1grad

If positive definite matrix Ω is a diagonal matrix, 1ei2(i=1,2,…,n) is the diagonal element, where ei is regarded as the hyper-ellipsoid axle. The hyper-ellipsoid defined by equation (5) generally takes the following form based on mathematical model of convex set theory, i.e. (12)E(δX,θ)={δX:δXTΩδX≤θ}={δX:∑i=1n(δX)2ei2≤θ2}
Where θ is the radius. If θ is not zero, the hyper-ellipsoid can be rewritten as E(δX,θ)={δX:∑i=1n(δX)2(θei)2≤1}
Then, equation (11) is rewritten as19 (13){g¯(X)=gmax=g0+θ∑i=1n(ei∂g(X0)∂xi)2g¯(X)=gmax=g0-θ∑i=1n(ei∂g(X0)∂xi)2

When the value of ei is equal to the uncertain deviation Δxi, i.e. ei=Δxi, the uncertain range defined by convex set is equal to the interval model. Therefore, equation (13) can be changed into (14){g¯(X)=gmax=g0+θ∑i=1n(Δxi∂g(X0)∂xi)2g¯(X)=gmax=g0-θ∑i=1n(Δxi∂g(X0)∂xi)2
With help of equations (2) and (14), the non-probabilistic reliability index η of convex model is obtained.

sec.title: Wear reliability analysis of swash-plate/slipper pad based on convex model
sec.p: The water hydraulic axial piston motor is under heavy, alternating loads. Besides, the axial piston motor also operates in high pressure and in high speed. Thus, there are many high-speed sliding friction pairs such as piston/cylinder sleeve, valve plate/cylinder port and swash-plate/slipper pad in a hydraulic motor. The failure of key friction pairs will lead to the failure of the hydraulic motor. Therefore, the reliability analysis of key frictions is extremely essential.

The main failure models of friction pairs are abrasion, scratching, melting and so on. Once the adhesion appears, it will quickly turn into melting. Owing to rapid increase in friction, local friction will lead to local temperature rise, which turns melting parts into soldering state. And then, if avulsion appears, the melting will happen; otherwise, the scratching will happen. Therefore, adhesion is unallowable in friction pairs. That is to say, for all friction pairs of hydraulic motor, the pv value (the sliding speed v multiples the mechanical contact stress p) must be controlled within the allowable range of the materials. If the limitation of material is exceeded, friction pairs will be failed too.

However, the water hydraulics is a new technology, and properties of most materials are not understood clearly. The relating data of the friction pair pv value is scant, and it is difficult to describe with a certain distribution function. However, probabilistic analysis needs to have sufficient information, and the interval model results tend to be more conservative than the convex model. Therefore, wear reliability model is employed to analyze and calculate the pv value of swash plate/slipper pad friction pair based on the convex model.

sec.title: pv value of the swash-plate/slipper pad
sec.p:
The force of piston-slipper is shown in Figure 1. Ignoring the inertial force of the piston bore caused by non-constant flow, the hydraulic clamping force caused by the piston structure, and axial hydraulic dynamics force in the gap between the piston-cylinder and the piston-slipper is mainly affected by the hydraulic force Fp, the return spring force Ft, the axial inertial force Fa, the friction force Ff caused by the axial inertial force, the centrifugal force Fl, the friction forces of F1 and F2, cylinder bore friction reaction forces R1 and R2, and the swash-plate support reaction force W.28 Figure 1.
The main force of piston-slipper.
With the coordinate system of Figure 1, the force equation on the Z-axis of piston-slipper is listed. (15)Wcosγ-F1-F2-Fp-Ft-Ff-Fa=0
The hydraulic force, return spring force, axial inertial force, friction force can be presented as, respectively (16)Fp=π4d2ps (17)Ft=k[xr+Rtanγ(1-cosϕ)] (18)Fa=-mza=-mzRω2tanγcosϕ (19)Ff=mzRω2f
Therefore, the whole axial force acting on the piston can be obtained (20)F=Fp+F1+F2+Ft+Fa+Ff

Because hydraulic force Fp is accounted for the majority of the axial force F (Xu29 pointed out that the rest of the force accounts for only 6% of the fluid force), equation (20) can be simplified as F≈1.06Fp. Therefore, equation (15) is rewritten as (21)W≈1.06Fpcosγ=1.06πd2ps4cosγ
The compaction force W' of the slipper is equal to the support reaction force W, then (22)W'=W≈1.06Fpcosγ=1.06πd2ps4cosγ
The hydraulic bearing thrust force of the slipper is expressed as (23)N=π8(d42-d32lnd4d3)ps
Using equations (22) and (23), the mechanical contact stress p between the slipper pad and swash-plate is expressed as28 (24)p=W'-NAx=psAx(1.06πd24cosγ-π8(d42-d32lnd4-lnd3))
The center linear velocity of the slipper is (25)v=Rωcos2α+sin2αcos2γ

From equation (25), it can be seen that the maximum velocity is vmax=Rω/cosγ; the minimum velocity is vmin=Rω. The extreme contact points of swash-plate and slipper pad are a and b (as shown in Figure 1). The distances of a and b to the rotation center are (R+d4cosγ/2-l'sinγ) and (R-d4cosγ/2+l'sinγ), respectively. The maximum and minimum values of v are easily obtained, respectively (26)vmax=ω(R+d4cosγ/2-l'sinγ)/cosγ (27)vmin=ω(R-d4cosγ/2+l'sinγ) (28)Letv=k1ω where k1∈[k1min,k1max] is defined as the structure factor of slipper, k1max=(R+d4cosγ/2-l'sinγ)/cosγ;k1min=R-d4cosγ/2+l'sinγ.

With equations (24) to (28), the pv value of the swash-plate/slipper pad can be obtained. (29)pv=psAx(1.06πd24cosγ-π8(d42-d32lnd4-lnd3))v=psAx(1.06πd24cosγ-π8(d42-d32lnd4-lnd3))k1ω=psAx(1.06πd24cosγ-π8(d42-d32lnd4-lnd3))k1(2π60n)=kpnpsk1 where kp is defined as (30)kp=2π60Ax(1.06πd24cosγ-π8(d42-d32lnd4-lnd3))

Besides revolving around the center line, the slipper also rotates round the slipper ball center randomly. The pv value for any point of the swash-plate/slipper pad varies between the maximum and minimum, and this change is stochastic. Therefore, the pv value of the swash-plate/slipper pad can be defined as an uncertain interval.

sec.title: Non-probabilistic wear reliability based on convex model
sec.p: The stress–strength interference model is used in analyzing reliability of the swash-plate/slipper pad. The actual (pv) value and the limited [pv] value of the friction pair are defined as stress and strength, respectively.14–16 With the stress–strength interference model, the state function of swash-plate/slipper pad is written as (31)M=[pv]-(pv)
With equations (29) to (31), the state function can be expressed as (32)M=[pv]-(pv)=[pv]-kpnpsk1

The (pv) value of the swash-plate/slipper pad is defined as an uncertain variable of interval parameters, where the input pressure ps,n,k1 vary in a certain range. Besides, the limited [pv] value also varies in a certain range. Therefore, [pv], ps,n,k1 can be assumed as bounded interval parameters. Based on convex set model theory, the upper and lower values of the function M=[pv]-(pv) is obtained through (33)MU=[pv]0-n0kpps0k10+[(Δ[pv])2+(Δnkpps0k10)2 +(n0kpΔpsk10)2+(n0k0ps0Δk1)2]1/2 (34)ML=[pv]0-n0kpps0k10-[(Δ[pv])2+(Δnkpps0k10)2 +(n0kpΔpsk10)2+(n0k0ps0Δk1)2]1/2 where [pv]0,ps0,n0,k10 are the mean value of [pv], ps,n,k1, respectively. Δ[pv],Δk1,Δn,Δps are the deviation of[pv], ps,n,k1, respectively. Apparently, only the bounds of uncertain parameters [pv],ps,n,k1 are needed.

Therefore, the non-probabilistic wear reliability index for the friction pair of swash plate/slipper pad can be gained as follows (35){η=McMr=MU+MLMU-MLMU=[pv]0-n0kpps0k10+[(Δ[pv])2 +(Δnkpps0k10)2+(n0kpΔpsk10)2 +(n0k0ps0Δk1)2]1/2ML=[pv]0-n0kpps0k10-[(Δ[pv])2 +(Δnkpps0k10)2+(n0kpΔpsk10)2 +(n0k0ps0Δk1)2]1/2

sec.title: Non-probabilistic wear reliability index
sec.p:
A water hydraulic motor is designed as the actuator of underwater tool (Figure 2). The rated rotating speed n is 1500 r/min, rated input pressure ps is 10 MPa. The matching material of swash-plate/slipper pad is to be hard versus soft. For the motor slipper, there are two kinds of structures (as shown in Figures 3 and 4), and their parameters are listed in Tables 1 and 2. Wear reliability of the two design schemes were calculated using the probabilistic model,14–16 the interval model30,31 and the convex model (deduced in part 2), respectively. Figure 2.
Water hydraulic motor used in underwater tool.
Figure 3.
Structure 1 of slipper pad.
Figure 4.
Structure 2 of slipper pad.
Table 1.
Data of structure 1.
Name Data Name Data
d3 (mm) 11.5 d4 (mm) 16
Ax (mm2) 97.2 D (mm) 14.2
k1(mm) [0.0181, 0.0283] ps (MPa) [9.0, 11.0]
[pv] (MPa·m/s) [11.22, 15.18] R (mm) 22.65
γ (°) 16 n (r/min) [1350, 1650]
l' (mm) 11.5 kp 0.2827
Table 2.
Data of structure 2.
Name Data Name Data
d1 (mm) 4 d4 (mm) 16
d2 (mm) 9.5 D (mm) 14.2
d3 (mm) 11.5 ps (MPa) [9.0, 11.0]
Ax (mm2) 155.51 R (mm) 22.65
k1 (mm) [0.0181, 0.0283] n (r/min) [1350, 1650]
[pv] (MPa·m/s) [11.22, 15.18] kp 0.1767
γ (°) 16 l' (mm) 11.5

The probabilistic reliability is calculated by the following equation, where the variables [pv], ps,n and k1 are considered as random variables of normal distribution. (36)β=[pv¯]-(pv¯)σ[pv]2+σ(pv)2 where [pv¯],(pv¯) are the mean value, respectively, σ[pv]2,σ(pv)2 are deviation, respectively. The calculating results of probabilistic wear reliability are listed in Table 3. Table 3.
Probabilistic wear reliability.
[pv¯] (pv¯) σ[pv]2 σ(pv)2 β R
Structure 1 13.2000 10.3008 0.6600 1.1140 2.2390 0.9916
Structure 2 13.2000 6.4380 0.6600 0.8662 6.2096 1

The non-probabilistic reliability based on the interval model is calculated by the following equation,30,31 where the variables [pv], ps,n and k1 are considered as interval variables. (37)η'=McMr=Rc+ScRr-Sr where Rc and Sc are the mean value of [pv] and (pv) respectively, and Rr and Sr are the deviation of [pv] and (pv) respectively. The calculating results of non-probabilistic wear reliability based on the interval model are listed in Table 4. Table 4.
Non-probabilistic wear reliability based on interval model.
Rc Rr Sc Sr η'
Structure 1 13.2 1.98 10.3008 4.3246 0.4599
Structure 2 13.2 1.98 6.4380 2.7028 1.4440

Using equation (35), the non-probabilistic wear reliability based on the convex model is obtained. The calculating results are listed in Table 5. Table 5.
Non-probabilistic wear reliability based on convex model.
Mc Mr MU ML η
Structure 1 2.8992 3.3244 6.2414 −0.4330 0.8675
Structure 2 6.7620 2.5985 9.3605 4.1635 2.6023

In comparison with Figures 3 and 4, it can be seen that the auxiliary support is added in structure 2. Therefore, the actual (pv) value of structure 2 is smaller than structure 1 calculated in equation (29). The smaller the actual (pv) value is, the higher the reliability of the structure is. Therefore, the structure 2 should be more reliable than structure 1. The calculated result in Table 5 of the convex model also verified that this is in accordance with the actual situation. Therefore, the convex model used to calculate the reliability analysis is credible.

In comparison with Tables 3 and 5, it can be seen that for structure 1, the probabilistic wear reliability index is β=2.2390 and the reliability is R=0.9916. Apparently, the wear reliability is not satisfactory. The non-probabilistic reliability index of the convex model is η=0.8675, η<1. According to the non-probabilistic reliability theory, this structure is not reliable too, which is consistent with the probabilistic method. For structure 2, the results of the two methods both show the structure is of high reliability. However, the convex model result is smaller compared with the probabilistic reliability.

Comprehensively, if the convex model result is reliable, the probabilistic result is inevitable reliable. On the contrary, if the convex model result is failure, the probabilistic result shows a large probability of failure. Therefore, when the technical information is insufficient, the reliability theory based on the convex model is a good option to be used to make reliability assessment.

In comparison with Tables 4 and 5, it can be seen that the upper bound of the convex model is lower than the interval model; the lower bound of the convex model is higher than the interval model. The wear reliability index based on the convex model is bigger than the ones based on the interval model. For structure 1, the results are η'=0.4599, η=0.8675; for structure 2, η'=1.4440, η=2.6023. That is to say, the interval model is more conservative than the convex model; the convex model is more economical and reasonable than the interval model. Therefore, the convex model is more suitable to make wear reliability analysis.

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis
sec.p:
The sensitivity of the non-probabilistic reliability index η based on the convex model is also analyzed. α is defined as the ratio of deviation to mean value. Figures 5 to 8 show the relations of wear reliability index η with the variables ps,n,k1 and [pv] for structure 2. From Figures 5 to 8 it can be seen that the system pressure and speed are the identical impact factors on the non-probabilistic reliability index η. The impacts of k1 and [pv] on η are greater than ps and n. The impact of [pv] on η is the greatest. The value of k1 is determined by the structure design, and [pv] is affected by the materials of friction pair. Therefore, materials and structure design are both important to the friction pair reliability, i.e. if the material choosing and structure design is suitable, the friction pair can keep reliability when the speed n and input pressure ps vary in a certain range. From Figures 5 to 8 it can be seen that the results are consistent with the actual situations,32,33 which verified the convex model. Figure 5.
The impact of system pressure ps.
Figure 6.
The impact of rotational speed n. Figure 7.
The impact of the structure factor of slipper k1. Figure 8.
The impact of [pv] value.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Probabilistic analysis needs sufficient information to obtain the probability distributions or the membership functions. In addition, the probabilistic model may turn out to be hyper-sensitive to perturbations of parameters so that small errors may lead to a serious mistake in calculating the structural reliability. This sensitivity shows that the absence of adequate statistical information in describing the probability model and the needed subjective assumptions may yield unreliable results. The convex model and interval model are two non-probabilistic methods based on non-probability indicators which need less uncertain information. However, the convex model is more economical, reasonable than the interval model. Considering the water hydraulic motor is expensive at present and scant information with uncertainty, the non-probabilistic reliability based on the convex model is more reasonable for analyzing the wear reliability of swash-plate/slipper pad.

In this research, the non-probabilistic wear reliability model for the friction pair of swash-plate/slipper pad is presented based on the convex model. The (pv) value is used to evaluate the wear reliability of swash-plate/slipper pad. The stress-strength interference model is chosen to set up the state function; the uncertain parameters are considered to change in a bounded convex set, namely a hyper-ellipsoid. With the first-order Taylor expansion, the boundary values of the state function are available, and the non-probabilistic wear reliability model is established using the non-probabilistic wear reliability index η. For the non-probabilistic reliability model, only the bounds on uncertain parameters are needed, instead of probabilistic density distribution or statistical quantities. The wear reliability analysis of the swash plate/slipper pad has illustrated the validity and feasibility of the presented method. This research provided a better approach to predict the reliability analysis of water hydraulic components when the system parameters concerned non-probabilistic but bounded uncertainties in the water hydraulic system. It is expected that the approach presented in this research will be used for further developments related to water hydraulics.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was funded by the Natural Science Foundations of China (No. 51075007), and National High technology Research and Development (863) Program of China (No. 2012AA091103).
